item.title: Louis Leblond
item.description:
Louis Leblond is the Director of Online Education in Physics and a Lecturer of Physics in the Eberly College of Science. He is also the first Tombros Fellow for Digital Learning. The Tombros Fellow of Digital Learning is a 1-year position and is responsible for the following:

  • Exploring new technologies for teaching practices by conceiving of, consulting on, and implementing new digital projects;
  • Considering research-based practices and potential mechanisms for assessment of the impacts digital technologies on student learning;
  • Sharing digital learning technologies and ideas by engaging with faculty in the college;
  • Working on public-facing projects, in resident instruction, world campus, or outreach projects, with potential for demonstrable benefits to students and ECoS;

    • Louis is working on creating an online version of PHYS 211 Mechanics and PHYS 212 Electrogmagnetism using a new tool called the IOLab, a multifunctional measuring device for physics labs.

    Dr. Leblond's other interests include:

    Online education, with a focus on developing (and assessing the efficacy) of new innovative learning tools in online education.

    Theoretical cosmology with particular emphasis on inflation, cosmic strings, dark matter and dark energy.

    High energy physics: string theory, quantum gravity and physics beyond the standard model with particular interests in the subjects of de Sitter spacetime and time-dependent backgrounds.

item.title: H5P - Documentation Tool
item.description: Are you searching for a creative, interactive, and engaging way to have students submit details about an assignment or project they’re working on? Would you like this information to be exported to a nicely formatted text document instantly? Look no further! H5P’s Documentation Tool allows you to create a project outline complete with instructions and assessment possibilities. In this video, I set up a simple demonstration that identifies some basic goals while also asking users to supply their insight as they traverse through each step. Specifically, we look over the general settings of the tool and work through building an example that will help users scaffold out a detailed steps-to-completion outline, create a plan of attack, and organize / assess individual goals and contributions. At the end, we'll review the different ways we can implement this newly created content into your website. Check it out!

item.title: Charles Lavera
item.description:
My name is Charles Lavera; I am a Multimedia Specialist / Web Developer with the Office of Digital Learning (ODL) at the Eberly College of Science at Penn State. Originally from the Pittsburgh area, I uphold a broad background in digital-media and web-development with a focus on Drupal-installations, web component architecture, interactive content (H5P), and open-source technology.

You could say that I wear many hats, but I consider my flexibility to be my greatest asset as I am able to provide support in a number of areas when needed. My favorite part of working with the ODL team has been the opportunity to collaborate with faculty and staff to create engaging web-experiences that showcase innovation and modern web-advancements. From complete websites to custom course-applications, we have fun exploring the deepest recesses of our creativity while we build a better future.

Outside of the office, I am known for being a loving husband, dedicated musician, an avid hockey fan, and a nature enthusiast.

item.title: Michael Potter
item.description:
Michael is an educational technologist who brings a decade’s worth of experience building websites and applications to the edtech space. His non-traditional path began at Penn State where he earned his BA in Political Science. From there, Michael joined a local venture capital group where he was involved with many different companies and handled everything from sales, to product development, to logistics and shipping. When one such company lost their only web developer, Michael was tapped to takeover the programming responsibilities and the rest is history. Michael was immediately hooked with web development and begin soaking up every piece of information the web could offer.

Since then, Michael has gained a wealth of experience in the full stack of web applications. His skillset is most notable in the area of front-end development and the Drupal framework. He has a passion for writing code, learning how to code, and mentoring fellow programmers. Michael has a unique gift for connecting, inspiring, and empowering others.

Innovative, forward thinking, risk taking are some of the reasons Michael wanted to work at ODL. His goal is to create technology and applications that remove barriers between educators and students. Michael believes that the web can enable people to change their lives for the better.

item.title: Carly Dreibelbis
item.description:
I have always been obsessed with visuals. When I was a kid I would go through my mom’s magazines, find an image I loved, check with my mom to make sure she didn’t need the article on the back, then clip it out and safely tuck it away in a flat, waxed-cardboard box under my bed - only to find out years later that my mom secretly snuck in my room and downsized my collection to keep it under control.

These days, I apply my passion for visual arts to graphic design and photography. I soak up inspiration all around me, and still tear out magazine ads and tuck them away for reference. I strive to visually present the facts and discipline of science with creativity, quality, technology and whenever possible… a bit of humor. I am always looking for new ways to approach courses, graphics, and content to successfully visually communicate concepts with an audience.

If I’m not behind a computer screen, you can find me outside with a camera by my side or in mad scientist mode in my kitchen - while tripping over a hungry cattle dog vacuum.

item.title: Biol 110
item.description:
Description

This course is a study of the evolution of the major groups of organisms including the fundamental concepts of biology. The goal of this course is to introduce you to fundamental concepts that are common to all organisms and to explore the biological diversity of life on Earth. Biology 110 is intended for students who need a majors-level introductory biology course and is not the best option for students who are looking for a general education course in science.

Objective

Biology 110 is a four credit course. The course will utilize web-based tutorials and laboratory sessions. The goal of this course is to introduce you to fundamental concepts that are common to all organisms and to explore the biological diversity of life on Earth.

Outline

2 Carbon and Life
3 Antiquity of Life
4 Prokaryotes I - Cellular and Genetic Organization
5 Prokaryotes II - Structure and Function
6 Prokaryotes III - Evolution and Early Metabolism
7 Subcellular Architecture of the Eukaryotic Cell

13 Fungi II - Phyla Ascomycota and Basidiomycota

15 Animals Two - Animals with Body Cavities: Pseudocoelomates and Protostome Coelomates
16 Animals Three - Animals with Body Cavities:Deuterostomes - Echinoderms and Chordates

The textbook is available in both electronic (etext) and hardcover formats. The textbook is not required but some students have found it to be a valuable supplement to the online tutorials to the course.

item.title: Biol 120N
item.description:
Description

This course is designed to introduce you to the discipline of plant biology and increase your awareness and appreciation of the impact of plants on your daily lives. The first part of the course will present the fundamentals of botany to provide you with a basic understanding of plant form and function. The rest of the course will be devoted to a survey of historical, cultural, and economic aspects of botany and related fields. We will finish up with an examination of the role of plants as an integral part of the world's ecosystem.

Objective

The purpose of Biology 120 is to introduce you to the fascinating world of plants with an emphasis on the historical, cultural, and economic uses.

Textbook

Levetin and McMahon, Plants and Society, 6th edition, McGraw-Hill. ISBN: 9780073524221

Course Schedule

Week Topic
1 Plants in Life and in History
2 Plant Anatomy and Physiology
3 Plant Genetics, Systematics, and Diversity
4 Plants and Dietary Needs
5 Grasses and Legumes
6 Starches and Carbohydrates: Feeding the Hungry World
7 Plant Fibers and Wood Products
8 A Foray into the Fungi
9 Herbs, Spices, Essential Oils, and Medicinal Plants
10 Poisonous and Psychoactive Plants
11 Stimulating Plant Beverages
12 Plants and the Environment

Grading

Type Points Percentage
3 Exams 200 each 40% of final grade
12 Lesson Assignments 75 60% of final grade

Proctor Information

You will need to secure a proctor in order to take exams in this course. A proctor will not automatically be assigned to you; rather, you must make the necessary contacts to secure a professional who will serve in this capacity.

  1. Contact a person who meets the qualifications and ask him or her to proctor your exam.
  2. Student Services must approve your proctor before any exams can be taken. Please see instructions for securing a suitable proctor . While many proctors will serve on a voluntary basis, you are responsible for paying any expenses incurred in retaining a proctor.
  3. You must submit your proctor for approval or schedule your exams at a testing center using our online proctored exam portal. You will need to enter your proctor's contact information and submit proctor verification documentation. Note: If your proctor has been previously approved by the World Campus during a prior course within two years, you do not need to obtain verification. World Campus retains proctor information on file for two years. To learn more about using the online portal, visit the World Campus website "Using the Proctored Exam Portal ."
  4. If your proctor does not meet the required specifications, Student Services will notify you within 5 to 7 business days.
  5. If you are a graduating senior requesting a final exam, please see additional information about early deadlines for course completion and exam scheduling.
  6. Contact Student Services if you cannot take a scheduled exam.
  7. Unless you have received permission to take your exam at an alternative time, your proctor will only allow you to take the exam during dates specified in your course.

item.title: BiSc 004
item.description:
Description

This course combines Human Anatomy, which is the study of parts of the human body, with Human physiology, which is the study of how parts of the body work together to make the body function. It is an introductory course for non-science majors, and it is hoped that you will develop a basic understanding about the human body that you will find useful when dealing with your own or a family member’s injury or illness in the future.

Assignments

All students are expected to complete the weekly assignments on time. These will be available for at least one week so budget your time accordingly. You are not able to complete all of your work for a month at one time and be done. This course is paced so you can progress through at a reasonable speed.

Each week there will be at least one lesson for you to study. Each lesson will have one quiz, one homework assignment, and textbook assignment (LearnSmart modules, Labs, etc.). Be aware that some weeks there may be more than one lesson, thus more than one quiz and homework/textbook assignments. Each of these have specific due dates listed on the folder in which you find them.

You may complete the homework and textbook assignments early as they will be available from the start of the semester. However, each quiz has a definite shelf life. Quizzes are meant to activate on a Saturday and deactivate on the following Sunday. That means you have more than a week to complete it. At no other time will you be able to view or complete quizzes, it is impossible to open up the quiz for a single person. The only exception to this is an instance of the quiz being improperly configured. If I short the class on time due an incorrect setting I will open up the quiz for additional time and everyone will have an opportunity to then complete it. However, that has been a rare event (but if it happens, notify the instructor). Pay attention to due dates, each assignment has one listed with the folder for that week.

The quizzes are set to overlap so you can manage your schedule if you happen to be away from a computer for an entire weekend. If you know that will happen then either get things out of the way very early or make it a point to finish the following weekend. Missing an assignment should never happen if you manage your time properly. You will be entirely responsible for your time and scheduling.

The weekly quizzes will be timed so it will not be possible to look up the answers to these questions at your leisure. The expectation is that you will study the content, gain some level of mastery of the terminology and take the tests to see how well you know everything. You are not to have access to sources of information when you take these tests, they are not open book.

The homework assignments may be completed ahead of schedule but not after the due date. Being late a day or two will result in a late penalty. Homework turned in after that will result in a zero. Homework assignments should not be copied from any other source, cited correctly or not. Many assignments will have you finding information from sources including the internet, however, a cut and paste job does not equal effort. Googling information is not considered an academic achievement.

Everything you write is expected to be your own work, not something you find and copy from the internet. It's perfectly clear when students have plagiarized a paragraph from a web page. It only takes 30 minutes to find a few web sites about a topic and then write up a summary of what you find. Don't risk University sanctions and an F for a homework assignment that should take less than an hour. See the statement on academic integrity for further information.

Late Assignments / Technical Difficulites

Since you have seven days in which to submit homework, and take a quiz, I will not accept illness or technical difficulties as an excuse to make up missed work. The only exception to this would be an extended hospitalization stay. All quizzes and homework message boards are available at the beginning of of the course. The due dates listed with each assignment are the last days that a quiz or homework assignment is available. To avoid missing deadlines, submit your work early and avoid waiting until the last evening at 11:55 pm to submit your homework or take a quiz. Your internet dropping out at the last possible minute to submit work is not a reasonable cause for being unable to complete work in a timely manner. Do not turn in work at the last possible minute. No scores will be dropped. Work cannot be turned in for a higher grade once a grade is assigned. There will be no opportunities to turn in extra work for extra credit. Be prepared to do the necessary work to reach your goals for a final grade.

Submitting Your Work

All course work will be submitted to your instructor through Canvas. To do this, you will need to:

  • Click on the Modules button in the menu bar at the left of this page
  • Choose the folder for the week we are currently in
  • Click on the homework assignment for the week
  • Type your answer into the text box
  • Click "submit assignment"
  • At the appropriate time click on the quiz for that week and complete it within the time specified or it will automatically submit whether you are finished or not

Grading

The Grading Scale can be found in the Getting Started section of Canvas. All grades can be found in Canvas by going to the Grades button on the left hand side.

Each lesson has a quiz that will vary in length between 10 and 20 points each. Some will be longer than others depending on the amount of material covered in a particular lesson.

Each quiz question is worth 1 point out of the total. Every question is worth exactly the same as any other question; only the length of the quiz each week will vary. Do not think in terms of percentage points here, this will be a point system based on total points.

Students will work on these assignments as an individual and will be responsible for completing them on time. Late assignments will have a deduction, assignments more than a couple of days late will not be accepted. Once we reach the end of the course it will not be possible to go back and complete work that is outdated by weeks or even months. Keep up on assignments to gain maximum points.

Grades are based on a combination of quizzes where each question is worth one point and various homework assignments worth a handful of points. All students are expected to complete the weekly quizzes on time. These will be available for at least one week so budget your time accordingly. You are not able to take all your tests at one time and be done. This course is paced so you can progress through at a reasonable speed.Each homework assignment has a specific number of points associated with it.

Any questions concerning a particular quiz or homework assignment must be resolved immediately. You cannot wait till the end of the semester to correct any problems. Due to time constraints, it will be impossible to review all assignments on the last day in the hope of finding one or two points to meet a grade cutoff. You should ask that all grading issues be resolved as they occur during the semester. No exams will be dropped; no extra credit will be accepted. It's impossible to evaluate hundreds of book reports or shoebox dioramas.

Deferred Grades

Students who are unable to complete the course because of illness or emergency may be granted a deferred grade which will allow the student to complete the course within the first six weeks of the following semester.

When a request for a deferred grade is supported by the instructor, the instructor indicates this approval by recording the deferred grade symbol (DF) for the student. The expiration date for the deferred grade is automatically recorded as the end of the sixth week of the next semester. Spring semester approvals expire during the fall semester unless the student enrolls during summer session. Therefore, course requirements must be completed and a grade must be submitted by the end of six weeks into the student’s next semester for which he or she is registered. Any deferred grade that is not replaced by the deadline will automatically become an F.

Note that deferred grades are limited to those students who can verify and document a valid reason for not being able to complete the last few assignments, not for gaining extra time to complete missing work from earlier in the semester. Students are expected to have completed at least 75% of the course assignments to be eligible for a deferment. For more information see DF grade.

item.title: Biol 11
item.description:
Description

You are a biological being, as are the foods that you eat. We use products from other organisms to make many of the clothes that we wear, build our homes, provide medicines, and give beauty to our lives. Therefore, developing an appreciation and understanding of the biological world is important to living in this world and becoming a responsible steward of its resources. Who hasn't watched a bird and wondered what it would be like to be able to fly? To see the world from a different perspective? This course will provide an introduction to fundamental biological topics (including cells, energy transduction, genetics, evolution, organismal structure/function, ecology) for non-majors in biology-related fields.

Objectives

By the time you complete this course, you should have learned about the following:

  • The role of natural selection, which shapes organisms in response to their environment through differential reproduction.
  • The mechanisms of inheritance, and how DNA encodes the genetic information for all living organisms.
  • The chemical basis of life, the origin of life on Earth, the structure and function of the two basic types of cells, and how cells utilize energy.
  • The fundamentals of plant biology, including plant structure, response, and reproduction.
  • The basic organization of the animal body, with a focus on the digestive and reproductive systems.
  • How organisms interact with each other and their environment, and how human activities have modified the environment for other organisms.

Course Schedule

Week Topic
1 Course Orientation
2 Evolution and Ecology
3 The Chemistry of Life
4 Cells
5 Exam 1
6 Energy & Life
7 How Cells Divide
8 Exam 2
9 Foundations of Genetics
10 How Genes Work
11 Evolution and Natural Selection
12 Exam 3
13 Plant Biology
14 The Animal Body
15 Ecosystems
16 Exam 4

Discussion Forums

Throughout the 11 lessons in this course, you will be expected to participate in discussions on a weekly basis. There are 15 participation points available for each lesson, for a total of 165 points. The quality of your participation will determine how many points you earn. If you fully answer the questions posted, in an original post with no quotes or copy and paste, then you will earn 7 pts. If you make 2 substantial replies to your classmates’ posts, then you will earn 4 pts each (8 pts total) for a total of 7 + 8 = 15 pts for each weekly discussion forum. No late submissions accepted. If you run into any difficulties, please email me asap.

Quizzes

Throughout the 11 lessons in this course, you will be expected to participate in multiple choice quizzes on a weekly basis. These short quizzes are to help you understand and apply the material being learned that week. You have one chance to take each untimed quiz before the weekly deadline. Upon submission of your completed quiz, it will be automatically graded, at 10 pts for each quiz.

Exams

Students are expected to take exams at the scheduled times. You will have plenty of advance warning as to when the exams are to take place. Please see the calendar. Contact me if there is a problem. Only legitimate excuses shall warrant a makeup exam to be taken as soon as possible. Legitimate excuses can include, but are not limited to, illness, family emergencies, trips, get called into work. Sleeping through the alarm is NOT a legitimate excuse! Neither is ‘my car broke down’ (bring me your mechanic’s bill) or ‘my ISP wasn’t working’----the least you can do is be creative! Each open, multiple choice exam is worth 100 pts and automatically graded after submission. No proctors required---but Penn State’s Academic Integrity policy is in effect. Upon submission of each exam, you are agreeing to abide by Penn State’s Academic Integrity policy.

item.title: BiSc 001
item.description:
Description

An exploration of how cellular structures and processes contribute to life and how life displays unity even in its diversity. Students who have passed BIOL 027, 110, or 141 may not schedule this course.

Objectives

At the end of this course, a successful student will be able to:

  1. Understand basic chemical processes that take place in living organisms, including organic compounds and the basic macromolecules.
  2. Identify cell organelles and describe their functions.
  3. Understand basic energy concepts and how enzymes and membranes function.
  4. Understand cellular respiration and photosynthesis and how they relate to each other.
  5. Understand the cell cycle, mitosis, and meiosis and how they differ.
  6. Understand basic genetics (inheritance, Mendel’s Laws, DNA structure and function, gene regulation, DNA technology).
  7. Understand basic population genetics and evolution (natural selection, genetic variation, gene pools).
  8. Understand the classification of organisms, taxonomy, and phylogenetics.
  9. Understand how the biological diversity on Earth originated and survey the major groups of organisms (prokaryotes, protists, fungi, plants, animals).
  10. Describe some of the issues in medical ethics that have arisen as a result of human tissue culture.

Attendance

You will be expected to check in every day or every other day for any announcements or updates. The amount of time spent looking over the material typically is correlated with quiz and exam grade: the more time spent studying usually translates into a better grade. Although this is an online course, you should expect to spend a similar amount of time on the material that you would for an in-person class. The general rule for studying is as follows: for every one hour of lecture, you should spend 2.5 to 3 hours studying the material. That means for a three-credit course, you should spend 7.5 to 9 hours per week studying and completing assignments if you intend to do well (“A” or “B” level).

Assignments

Weekly Quizzes

Each week a short quiz (about 15 minutes) will be made available on Canvas, covering the material from the previous week’s subject(s). Each quiz will be made available starting at 12:01 AM on Monday and will run through 11:59 PM on Wednesday. This is designed to ensure that you keep up with your reading and study. The quizzes will be in a true/false, matching, or multiple-choice type format and are intended to reinforce the main concepts in each chapter. These quizzes will only be open for a limited time, so do not go for extended periods of time (days, weeks) without having logged into the course. I typically do not re-open quizzes unless in the case of technical difficulties from my end. If you miss one or a few quizzes, this will not negatively affect your grade. If you have taken all 14 quizzes, only your 10 best scores will count towards your grade.

Book Discussions

Each week, we will have discussions on Canvas about the book The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks by Rebecca Skloot. These discussions will consist of one or more discussion questions posted by the instructor, which you will respond to and discuss. The first response will take place within three days of the initial discussion question post and will be at minimum 250 words (longer posts are welcome but will not necessarily improve your grade. Quality of post and not quantity will determine your score). After everyone has had a chance to make an initial response, you will make thoughtful comments on other students’ posts on the thread. These comments will be respectful (no name calling, threats, trolling, etc.) even if one does not agree with the post in question. The normal Penn State guidelines prohibiting harassment and hate speech will be in place and will be enforced. We can discuss controversial topics like adults because we are adults.

Midterm Exam

Approximately every 4 weeks, you will have a midterm exam over the material covered. These exams will include true/false, multiple-choice, and/or matching questions; in addition there may be diagrams to label and/or short free-response questions. Exams will cover material for each “unit”: Exam 1 will cover material from the beginning of the course until the first exam, Exam 2 will cover material after Exam 1 until the second exam, and so forth. These will be delivered online, but they will be proctored using Examiny software. You will have a window of about 72 hours to take your exam, but you must schedule it in advance through the Examiny tab in Canvas. If you make changes to your scheduled exam time less than 24 hours before the start of the exam window, Examiny will charge you a fee of $3.

Final Exam

The final will be similar in format to the midterm exams. The only differences will be that the final will be slightly (about 50%) longer, and will be cumulative . The cumulative section will be about 33% of the final, and the remainder will be material covered after the third midterm. The final should be scheduled during Finals Week.

Grading

  • Book Discussions: 250
  • Weekly Quizzes (Best 10 out of 14) 30 pts/each: 300
  • Midterm Exams (3, 100 pts/each): 300
  • Final Exam: 150

item.title: BiSc 003
item.description:
Description

The purpose of BI SC 003 is to help you prepare for living in the 21st century in a sustainable way. Through the course, you will come to realize that you are dependent upon and supported by natural systems, without which life on earth could not exist. By presenting ideas and concepts about living systems and their environment, it is hoped that an understanding of these biological and ecological principles and their application towards current environmental problems will give you the confidence to be a trustworthy instrument for healthy development, a conscientious steward of nature and an agent of change towards a sustainable society.

Objectives

  • Evaluate your worldview (your own personal belief system), which shapes the way you currently think about the environment and environmental issues.
  • Outline important events in the history of environmentalism.
  • Explain basic ecological concepts and natural laws of matter and energy and how they relate to environmental issues.
  • Classify and describe biomes in the United States.
  • Discuss causes, effects and solutions to these major environmental issues:
    • Overpopulation
    • Food Production
    • Habitat Destruction
    • Urbanization and Urban Sprawl
    • Energy Use and Abuse
    • Preservation of Biodiversity
    • Conservation of erreplaceable Natural Resources
    • Global Climate Change
    • Water Use and Abuse
    • Solid Waste Management
    • Affluenza and Overconsumption
  • Use critical thinking and evaluate environmental information sources.
  • Apply information and tools necessary to minimize your environmental impact in meaningful ways if you choose to do so.

Course Materials

The following text book is required. It may be purchased from MBS Direct, or rented/purchased from other sources:

  • Principles of Environmental Science: Inquiry and Applications, 8th Edition, Cunningham and Cunningham, published by McGraw-Hill, 2016. ISBN: 9780078036071
  • MBS Direct: Loose-Leaf version of the same book. ISBN: 9781260722666. You can buy or rent either version.

Reading and Lectures

For each of the 12 lessons in this course you should read the assigned chapter(s) in the text book and watch/listen to a 20-25 minute lecture located on the course web-site, or read the transcript of the lecture.

Exams

There will be two proctored exams in this course, one mid-course exam covering lessons 1-6, and one final exam covering lessons 7-12. Each exam will be available in Canvas for a 7 day period as outlined in the course schedule. You will only be able to open each exam once and you will then have 2 hours to complete all the questions. The exams will be proctored with Examity and you are not permitted to use the text book or notes while taking the exams. Exam questions will assess your understanding of the course materials.

Each exam consists of 40 multiple choice questions worth 3 points each (total 120 points), and 8 short answer questions worth 10 points each (total 80 points). Each exam is 200 points total and 20% of the course grade.

Exam Late Submission Policy: If you miss the exam deadline you may contact the instructor to ask to take a make-up exam. Unless you have a valid, documented reason for missing the exam period you will lose 10% per day taking the exam late.

Assignments

For each of the 12 lessons there will be 1-3 assignments. See course schedule for due dates for individual assignments.

Course Introduction Activities (25 points): During week 1 you will complete several course introduction activities:

  • Class introduction, post in “Class Introductions” discussion forum (1 point)
  • Examity Profil and Mid-course Exam scheduling (1 point)
  • Syllabus quiz (2 points)
  • Academic Integrity Contract (1 point)
  • Complete pre-course environmental science quiz and submit comments to this quiz in drop box. The purpose is to see how much you already know about environmental issues and no worries; you can get full credit for this activity even with a low score on the quiz (10 points).
  • Evaluating Information Sources (10 points).

Discussion Forums (15- 30 points)

In the discussion forums you will get a chance to discuss environmental issues with your classmates. You will write your answer to a set of questions in a short essay format and post this in the discussion forum, in addition to replying to at least two of your classmates’ posts (one in the information literacy discussion, three in climate change discussion). Participate by the deadlines outlined in the course schedule.

Grading Criteria: To obtain full credit for participation in the discussion forums you need to post well-written, reflective main response that meets all the requirements outlined in description, and write at least two (three in climate change discussion) substantial replies to your classmates’ postings. A simple "I agree with you" is not enough, you should instead try to ask thought-provoking questions, add supporting information, or state your opposing views that contributes to your classmates’ learning.

Quizzes (10-30 points each)

Each quiz will consist of multiple choice and short answer questions. Quizzes are open book/notes and there is no time limit. Submit by the deadlines outlined in the course schedule.

Case Studies (20 points each)

You will research one specific example that relates to a topic covered in the required reading/lecture and summarize your findings in a 300-500 word essay.

  1. The history of the Environmental Movement - Choose one person or organization
  2. Endangered or Invasive Species - choose one species
  3. Deforestation - choose one country

Submit in assignment folders by the deadlines outlined in the course schedule. Note: The originality of your case study assignments will be checked through Turnitin.

Grading Criteria: Full credit will be awarded if all the requirements outlined in the description are met, all questions are answered correctly/ thoroughly and assignment is submitted by the deadline. See grading rubrics for more detail.

Video Assignments (15-20 points each)

You will watch one or several short videos that relate to topics covered in the required reading/lecture and then answer a set of questions. Submit in drop box by deadlines outlined in the course schedule.

Grading Criteria: Full credit will be awarded if all questions are answered correctly/thoroughly and submitted by the deadline.

Projects (15-50 points each)

  1. Biodiversity (30 points): Surveying biodiversity in your neighborhood or nearby natural ecosystem (going for a walk and web research)
  2. Food (20 points): Keeping track of and evaluating the impact of the food you eat (kitchen, potentially restaurants, and web research)
  3. Energy (50 points): Researching pros and cons of non-renewable and renewable energy source
  4. Ecological Footprint (15 points): Calculating your ecological footprint (web-activity). Submit in drop box by deadlines outlined in the course schedule.

Grading Criteria: Full credit will be awarded if all the requirements outlined in the description are met, all questions are answered correctly/ thoroughly and assignment is submitted by the deadline. See grading rubrics for more detail.

Extra Credit – Polls/Surveys (2 points each)

Throughout the semester you will get a chance to participate in a few polls/surveys. You will get 2 extra credit points for each poll/survey you participate in if you do so by the corresponding lesson’s submission deadline. Zero points for late participation in polls/surveys. There will also be a 10 extra credit point discussion forum associated with lesson 12.

Use proper English when writing assignments, participating in class discussions and completing exams; achieving competence in the use of the English language is one of the objectives of general education at Penn State. Improper use of the English language, including more than a few minor spelling and grammatical errors, will adversely affect your grade.

Grading

This course consists of 12 lessons. For each lesson you will read one (or two) chapter(s) in the text book, watch a power point lecture and complete 1-3 assignments. Assignments associated with each lesson add up to approximately 50 points. 15 points are associated with the course introductory activities. See course format for assignment descriptions and course schedule for deadlines for each assignment.

item.title: BiSc 002
item.description:
Description

This course combines Genetics, Human Genetics, Evolution and Ecology. It is an introductory course for non-science majors, and it is hoped that you will develop a basic understanding of genetic and biological terms and their importance to our technologically advanced society. Evolution is a central theme of biology and it helps us to understand the process of life that is ongoing all across our globe. The interactions among members of that global community provide the backdrop for understanding the ecology of our planet and our place in that community. There are no prerequisites for this course.

Assignments

All students are expected to complete the weekly quizzes on time. These will be available for at least one week so budget your time accordingly. You are not able to take all of your tests at one time and be done. This course is paced so you can progress through at a reasonable speed.

Each week there will be at least one lesson for you to study. Each lesson will have one quiz, one homework assignment, and textbook assignment (LearnSmart modules, Labs, etc.). Be aware that some weeks there may be more than one lesson, thus more than one quiz and homework/textbook assignments. Each of these have specific due dates listed on the folder in which you find them.

You may complete the homework and textbook assignments early as they will be available from the start of the semester. However, each quiz has a definite shelf life. Quizzes are meant to activate on a Saturday and deactivate on the following Sunday. That means you have more than a week to complete it. At no other time will you be able to view or complete quizzes, it is impossible to open up the quiz for a single person. The only exception to this is an instance of the quiz being improperly configured. If I short the class on time due an incorrect setting I will open up the quiz for additional time and everyone will have an opportunity to then complete it. However, that has been a rare event (but if it happens, notify the instructor). Pay attention to due dates, each assignment has one listed with the folder for that week.

The quizzes are set to overlap so you can manage your schedule if you happen to be away from a computer for an entire weekend. If you know that will happen then either get things out of the way very early or make it a point to finish the following weekend. Missing an assignment should never happen if you manage your time properly. You will be entirely responsible for your time and scheduling.

The weekly quizzes will be timed so it will not be possible to look up the answers to these questions at your leisure. The expectation is that you will study the content, gain some level of mastery of the terminology and take the tests to see how well you know everything. You are not to have access to sources of information when you take these tests, they are not open book.

The homework assignments may be completed ahead of schedule but not after the due date. Being late a day or two will result in a late penalty. Homework turned in after that will result in a zero. Homework assignments should not be copied from any other source, cited correctly or not. Many assignments will have you finding information from sources including the internet, however, a cut and paste job does not equal effort. Googling information is not considered an academic achievement.

Everything you write is expected to be your own work, not something you find and copy from the internet. It's perfectly clear when students have plagiarized a paragraph from a web page. It only takes 30 minutes to find a few web sites about a topic and then write up a summary of what you find. Don't risk University sanctions and an F for a homework assignment that should take less than an hour. See the statement on academic integrity for further information.

Late Assignments / Technical Difficulites

Since you have seven days in which to submit homework, and take a quiz, I will not accept illness or technical difficulties as an excuse to make up missed work. The only exception to this would be an extended hospitalization stay. All quizzes and homework message boards are available at the beginning of of the course. The due dates listed with each assignment are the last days that a quiz or homework assignment is available. To avoid missing deadlines, submit your work early and avoid waiting until the last evening at 11:55 pm to submit your homework or take a quiz. Your internet dropping out at the last possible minute to submit work is not a reasonable cause for being unable to complete work in a timely manner. Do not turn in work at the last possible minute. No scores will be dropped. Work cannot be turned in for a higher grade once a grade is assigned. There will be no opportunities to turn in extra work for extra credit. Be prepared to do the necessary work to reach your goals for a final grade.

Submitting Your Work

All course work will be submitted to your instructor through Canvas. To do this, you will need to:

  • Click on the Modules button in the menu bar at the left of this page.
  • Choose the folder for the week we are currently in.
  • Click on the homework assignment for the week.
  • Type your answer into the text box
  • Click "submit assignment"
  • At the appropriate time click on the quiz for that week and complete it within the time specified or it will automatically submit whether you are finished or not.

Grading

The Grading Scale can be found in the Getting Started section of Canvas. All grades can be found in Canvas by going to the Grades button on the left hand side.

Each lesson has a quiz that will vary in length between 10 and 20 points each. Some will be longer than others depending on the amount of material covered in a particular lesson.

Each quiz question is worth 1 point out of the total. Every question is worth exactly the same as any other question; only the length of the quiz each week will vary. Do not think in terms of percentage points here, this will be a point system based on total points.

Students will work on these assignments as an individual and will be responsible for completing them on time. Late assignments will have a deduction, assignments more than a couple of days late will not be accepted. Once we reach the end of the course it will not be possible to go back and complete work that is outdated by weeks or even months. Keep up on assignments to gain maximum points.

Grades are based on a combination of quizzes where each question is worth one point and various homework assignments worth a handful of points. All students are expected to complete the weekly quizzes on time. These will be available for at least one week so budget your time accordingly. You are not able to take all your tests at one time and be done. This course is paced so you can progress through at a reasonable speed.Each homework assignment has a specific number of points associated with it.

Any questions concerning a particular quiz or homework assignment must be resolved immediately. You cannot wait till the end of the semester to correct any problems. Due to time constraints, it will be impossible to review all assignments on the last day in the hope of finding one or two points to meet a grade cutoff. You should ask that all grading issues be resolved as they occur during the semester. No exams will be dropped; no extra credit will be accepted. It's impossible to evaluate hundreds of book reports or shoebox dioramas.

Deferred Grades

Students who are unable to complete the course because of illness or emergency may be granted a deferred grade which will allow the student to complete the course within the first six weeks of the following semester.

When a request for a deferred grade is supported by the instructor, the instructor indicates this approval by recording the deferred grade symbol (DF) for the student. The expiration date for the deferred grade is automatically recorded as the end of the sixth week of the next semester. Spring semester approvals expire during the fall semester unless the student enrolls during summer session. Therefore, course requirements must be completed and a grade must be submitted by the end of six weeks into the student’s next semester for which he or she is registered. Any deferred grade that is not replaced by the deadline will automatically become an F.

Note that deferred grades are limited to those students who can verify and document a valid reason for not being able to complete the last few assignments, not for gaining extra time to complete missing work from earlier in the semester. Students are expected to have completed at least 75% of the course assignments to be eligible for a deferment. For more information see DF grade.

item.title: Astro 140
item.description:
Description

The possible existence of life beyond Earth is one of the most fundamental questions relating the human race to the physical Universe around us. While considerations of extraterrestrial life were in the domains of philosophy and science fiction in the past, today we have considerable scientific knowledge that can be applied to the question. Advances in modern astronomy have dramatically improved our understanding of our cosmic surroundings: tracing the cosmic origins of biological molecules, direct evidence for planets around most stars (exoplanets), and a deeper understanding of planet formation have all emerged in the past generation. Several fields -- geology, biochemistry, paleontology (fossils), evolutionary biology -- give insight (though not a complete understanding) on how life arose on Earth, and spacecraft travel provides constraints on life elsewhere in our Solar System.

The results from studies on Earth, the Solar System, and exoplanets across the Galaxy together indicate that the conditions for life are widespread in the Universe; extraterrestrial life has not been found yet, but does not seem implausible. Interstellar space travel between habitable planets, by humans or other beings, is exceedingly difficult but not physically impossible. The course is thus rooted in modern science, but is connected to the long-standing philosophical question: Are we alone in the Universe? Today, this question is often embedded in science fiction (such as movies about aliens) and discussion about whether aliens have visited Earth. Today, astronomical studies are leading the way in answering part of the question: Earth-like planets seems to be extremely common. But there is no evidence yet for life outside of Earth.

Activities

Part of the course resembles a traditional classroom learning environment: We have lectures by the instructor (online rather than in person), read chapters of our textbook, and take quizzes to evaluate that we have learned the material. But the course also has more (inter)active assignments: students participate in discussion forums; take part in a huge citizen science research effort; and engage in science writing, producing two papers. The result is a multifaceted learning experience, blending more passive knowledge acquisition with more active learning processes.

Outline

The course is divided into five broad themes that are, in turn, divided into several topics. The course is designed as a 15-week course with a new Web page environment for each week. Readings from our textbook, {selected textbook for the semester} associated with each week are listed.

Theme I: Introduction and astronomical context (Weeks 1 - 2)

  1. Cosmology: The history of the Universe
  2. Stars: Energy for life

Theme II: Life on Earth (Weeks 3 - 4)

  1. Biochemistry & Origin of Life
  2. Early Life & Earth's Atmosphere

Theme III: Life elsewhere in the Solar System

  1. Review of our Solar System
  2. Possibility of life on Mars
  3. Possibility of life in the outer Solar System

Theme IV: Planetary systems in the galaxy (Weeks 8 - 11)

  1. Discovering Exoplanets (PlanetHunter Activity)
  2. Census and properties of Exoplanets
  3. Census and properties of Exoplanets (Continued)
  4. The formation of Planetary Systems

Theme V: Life around other stars (Weeks 12 - 14)

  1. Possibility of life in other planetary systems
  2. Searching for extraterrestrial life
  3. Interstellar Travel

Theme VI: Philosophical perspectives (Week 15)

Materials

The following material is required and may be purchased from MBS Direct:

Textbook (varies)

It is important that students have this book, as we will read most of it during 12 of the 15 weeks of the course. For pricing and ordering information, please see the MBS Direct Web page for Astro 140. MBS Direct can also be contacted at 1-800-325-3252. It may also be purchased from Barnes & Noble, Amazon.com or other book vendors, but delivery to non-U.S. locations may be slow. MBS Direct promises rapid delivery.

Many of Penn State's library resources can be utilized from a distance. Through the Library Resources and Services for Off-Campus Users Web site, you can...

  • Access magazine, journal, and newspaper articles online using library databases
  • Borrow materials and have them delivered to your doorstep...or even your desktop
  • Ask a librarian for research help via e-mail, chat, or phone using the ASK! service
  • ...and much more!

NOTE: You must have an active Penn State Access Account to take full advantage of the Libraries' resources and services. Once you have a Penn State account, you will automatically be registered with the library within 24-48 hours. If you would like to check that your library registration has been completed, visit the Library's homepage, click on "My Library Accounts" and then click on "CAT Account".

Grading

Quizzes (48%)

Four times during the semester after a Theme is completed, students will take a quiz on recent material covered in the class, associated reading and online material. The quizzes will last 40 minutes and have combinations of multiple choice, short answer and short essay questions. Students may have access to notes and the textbook, but study prior to the quiz is necessary because of the time constraint. Quizzes are taken in Penn State's ANGEL Web environment. Students can take the quiz anytime during specified 4-day periods from early-Friday to end-of-day Monday. Quizzes are `open book, open Web' format without proctoring; however, they are timed so that students are who are not familiar with the material cannot perform well. Each Quiz is worth 12% of the course grade.

Science Writing Papers (27%)

Students will submit two original papers using topics and resources provided by (or in agreement with) the instructor. The goal is to learn techniques of science writing: the papers review scientific findings and will present them in a formal style. General guidence is given here, and the student and instructor interact individually on Paper #1. The student then writes Paper #2 on their own; it is the same length as Paper #1 but is worth more points as the student can incorporate what they have leared about science writing. There are three deadlines: a draft of Paper 1, the final version of Paper 1 and, at the beginning of Exam Week, delivery of Paper 2. Details on science writing, paper requirements, and sample topics are given here. Paper #1 is worth 12% of the course grade, and Paper #2 is worth 15% of the course grade.

Discussion Forums (15%)

Throughout the course, we will hold informal discussions on through PSU's ANGEL, and optionally VoiceThread, environment. The instructor will start with a question, sometimes accompanied with on-line material. Students then participate with independent or secondary commentaries. Points are earned by number and quality of contributions; contributions based on factual material is preferred over informal opinions. The maximum contribution is 15% of the course grade.

PlanetHunters Activity (10%)

During Weeks 8-9, students will engage in the Zooniverse `citizen science' activity PlanetHunters. This involves a training session, classification of ~30 lightcurves from NASA's Kepler mission for possible planet transits, and completion of a worksheet and analysis. The goal is to examine observations from the Kepler observations of ~200,000 stars, characterizing the variability of the star and looking for periodic dips in brightness due to transiting planets.

At the end of the semester, course grades (A/A-/B+/B/B-/C+/C/D/F) will be calculated on a `curve' based on the instructor's judgment of class performance. Throughout the semester, each student can access their grades for past work on the ANGEL gradebook.
